MEDROXYPROGESTERONE ACETATE

  • Indications and doses
  • Pregnancy
  • Hepatic impairment
  • Renal impairment
  • Contra indications
  • Side effects
  • Patient and carer advice
  • Cautions
  • conception and contraception
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Dysfunctional uterine bleeding,

By mouth

  • For adults
    2.5–10 mg daily for 5–10 days, repeated for 2 cycles, begin treatment on day 16–21 of cycle.

Secondary amenorrhoea,

By mouth

  • For adults
    2.5–10 mg daily for 5–10 days, repeated for 3 cycles, begin treatment on day 16–21 of cycle.

Mild to moderate endometriosis,

By mouth

  • For adults
    10 mg 3 times a day for 90 consecutive days, begin treatment on day 1 of cycle.

Progestogenic opposition of oestrogen HRT,

By mouth

  • For adults
    10 mg daily for the last 14 days of each 28-day oestrogen HRT cycle.

Endometrial cancer, Renal cell cancer,

By mouth

  • For adults
    200–600 mg daily.

Breast cancer,

By mouth

  • For adults
    0.4–1.5 g daily.

Contraception,

By subcutaneous injection

  • For adults females of childbearing potential
    150 mg, to be administered within the first 5 days of cycle or within first 5 days after parturition (delay until 6 weeks after parturition if breast-feeding).
  • For adults females of childbearing potential
    104 mg, to be administered within first 5 days of cycle or within 5 days postpartum (delay until 6 weeks postpartum if breast-feeding), injected into anterior thigh or abdomen, dose only suitable if no hormonal contraceptive use in previous month.

Long-term contraception,

By subcutaneous injection

  • For adults females of childbearing potential
    150 mg every 12 weeks, to be administered within the first 5 days of cycle or within first 5 days after parturition (delay until 6 weeks after parturition if breast-feeding).
  • For adults females of childbearing potential
    104 mg every 13 weeks, to be administered within first 5 days of cycle or within 5 days postpartum (delay until 6 weeks postpartum if breast-feeding), injected into anterior thigh or abdomen, dose only suitable if no hormonal contraceptive use in previous month.

Contraception (when patient changing from other hormonal contraception),

By subcutaneous injection

  • For adults females of childbearing potential
    (consult product literature).

Advice when patient is pregnant

With oral use

Avoid—genital malformations and cardiac defects reported.

With intramuscular use or subcutaneous use

Not known to be harmful.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

With oral use

Avoid in hepatic impairment.

With intramuscular use or subcutaneous use

Caution in severe liver disease and recurrent cholestatic jaundice.

Avoid in liver tumour.

Advice regarding renal impairment

When used for Mild to moderate endometriosis or Progestogenic opposition of oestrogen HRT or Dysfunctional uterine bleeding or Secondary amenorrhoea

Use with caution.

Contra indications

  • Acute porphyrias
  • severe arterial disease
  • undiagnosed vaginal bleeding

Known side effects

General side effects

notKnown: Breast discomfort, changes in libido, depression, dizziness, headache, indigestion, loss of vision during treatment (discontinue treatment if papilloedema or retinal vascular lesions), menstrual irregularities, nausea, pruritus, vomiting, weight gain,

Specific side effects

rare: osteoporosis, osteoporotic fractures, osteoporosis, osteoporotic fractures,

notKnown: disturbance of appetite, injection site-reactions, reduced bone mineral density, skin disorders, acne, adrenergic-like effects (when used for malignant disease), alopecia, anaphylactoid reactions, bloating, breast tenderness, cervical erosions (when used for malignant disease), confusion (when used for malignant disease), congestive heart failure (when used for malignant disease), constipation (when used for malignant disease), diarrhoea (when used for malignant disease), drowsiness, dry mouth (when used for malignant disease), euphoria (when used for malignant disease), fluid retention, galactorrhoea (when used for malignant disease), glucocorticoid effects may lead to a cushingoid syndrome (with high doses for malignant disease), hirsutism, hypercalcaemia (when used for malignant disease), hyperpyrexia (when used for malignant disease), hypertension (when used for malignant disease), insomnia, jaundice, loss of concentration (when used for malignant disease), nervousness (when used for malignant disease), palpitation (when used for malignant disease), premenstrual-like syndrome, raised platelet count (when used for malignant disease), raised white blood cell count (when used for malignant disease), rash, retinal thrombosis (when used for malignant disease), skin reactions, tachycardia (when used for malignant disease), urticaria, vision disorders (when used for malignant disease), disturbance of appetite, injection site-reactions, reduced bone mineral density, skin disorders,

With intramuscular use or subcutaneous use

Cervical cancer

Use of injectable progestogen-only contraceptives may be associated with a small increased risk of cervical cancer, similar to that seen with combined oral contraceptives. The risk of cervical cancer with other progestogen-only contraceptives is not yet known.

With intramuscular use or subcutaneous use

Reduction in bone mineral density occurs in the first 2–3 years of use then stabilises.

Advice for patients and carers

With intramuscular use or subcutaneous use

Full counselling backed by patient information leaflet required before administration—likelihood of menstrual disturbance and the potential for a delay in return to full fertility. Delayed return of fertility and irregular cycles may occur after discontinuation of treatment but there is no evidence of permanent infertility.

Cautions regarding administration

  • Possible risk of breast cancer
  • With intramuscular use: history during pregnancy in disturbances of lipid metabolism
  • With intramuscular use: history during pregnancy of deterioration of otosclerosis
  • With intramuscular use: history during pregnancy of pruritus
  • With oral use: asthma
  • With oral use: cardiac dysfunction
  • With oral use: conditions that may worsen with fluid retention
  • With oral use: diabetes (progestogens can decrease glucose tolerance—monitor patient closely)
  • With oral use: epilepsy
  • With oral use: history of depression
  • With oral use: hypertension
  • With oral use: migraine
  • With oral use: susceptibility to thromboembolism (particular caution with high dose)
  • With subcutaneous use: history during pregnancy in disturbances of lipid metabolism
  • With subcutaneous use: history during pregnancy of deterioration of otosclerosis
  • With subcutaneous use: history during pregnancy of pruritus

Advice regarding conception and contraception

With intramuscular use

If interval between dose is greater than 12 weeks and 5 days (in long-term contraception), rule out pregnancy before next injection and advise patient to use additional contraceptive measures (e.g. barrier) for 14 days after the injection.

With subcutaneous use

If interval between dose is greater than 13 weeks and 7 days (in long-term contraception), rule out pregnancy before next injection.

Prepared medicinal forms of MEDROXYPROGESTERONE ACETATE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: oral suspension, oral solution,
Tablet
Suspension for injection
